sets.name: Dragon Dance (Fire)
sets.description: Mega Charizard X is a ferocious wallbreaker and setup sweeper, aiding Fire teams in matchups like Dragon, Fire, and Electric. Tough Claws-boosted Flare Blitz fires off nuclear-powered attacks, heavily denting walls such as Mandibuzz, Gliscor, and Mega Sableye. Dragon Claw, also powered up by Tough Claws, threatens Garchomp, Rotom-W, and Kommo-o. Earthquake threatens switch-ins like Toxapex, Skeledirge, and Heatran, while Roost increases Mega Charizard X's longevity and mitigate recoil damage from Flare Blitz. Alternatively, Thunder Punch may be used to deal more damage to Slowbro, Pelipper, and Tapu Fini while still retaining super effective coverage against Toxapex. Volcarona is an exceptional teammate, as it threatens physical walls such as Slowbro, Toxapex, and Hippowdon after a Quiver Dance. Torkoal supports Mega Charizard X with sun to boost Flare Blitz's power and remove rain, Stealth Rock to wear down switch-ins, and Rapid Spin to remove entry hazards. Rotom-H sets up Reflect and Light Screen to ease Mega Charizard X's setup process and offers pivoting with Volt Switch. Choice Scarf Blacephalon is a great late-game cleaner and is appreciated to wear down troublesome walls like Skeledirge and Slowbro as well as cripple Toxapex and Porygon2 with Trick. Heatran traps and withers down Toxapex with Magma Storm and prevents Stealth Rock from being set up using Taunt. Cinderace provides entry hazard control with Court Change and brings Mega Charizard X in using U-turn.

sets.name: Choice Specs (Electric)
sets.description: With Choice Specs equipped, Zapdos's already amazing Special Attack is boosted to even greater heights, turning it into an incredible wallbreaker. Its Flying typing also grants an invaluable Ground immunity for Electric teams. Hurricane is Zapdos's most powerful move, threatening a variety of Pokemon that resist or are immune to Electric such as Mega Venusaur and Gastrodon. Heat Wave beats Steel-types such as Mega Scizor, Iron Treads, and Ferrothorn, thus making it an incredible asset in the Steel and Grass matchups. Hidden Power Ice cleanly OHKOes Gliscor, Landorus-T, and Garchomp; alternatively, Hidden Power Grass can be used if reliably eliminating Gastrodon and Swampert is more important. Volt Switch lets Zapdos switch out of its checks like Tyranitar and Blissey, keeping momentum in favor of Zapdos's team. As dangerous as Zapdos is, it is highly susceptible to Stealth Rock; hence, Rotom-W is a great partner that can use Defog while also helping Zapdos beat Ground-types thanks to Hydro Pump. Iron Hands and Zeraora help Zapdos wallbreak by wearing down special walls like Heatran, Blissey, and Clodsire. Regieleki and Alolan Raichu can take advantage of Zapdos weakening teams and removing Ground-types so that they can clean up with their deadly Rising Voltage later in the game.

sets.name: Utility (Ghost)
sets.description: Mega Sableye is a staple on bulkier Ghost teams due to its Dark typing, great abilities before and after Mega Evolution, and great defensive stats. Knock Off hinders Chansey and Porygon2 for Mega Sableye's wallbreaking teammates and eases the matchup against Landorus and Nidoking. Due to Sableye's meager HP and need for longevity, Recover's a must-have utility option, further enabling Metal Burst. Protect allows Sableye to Mega Evolve safely, ensuring it can utilize Magic Bounce later into the game. Metal Burst retaliates against Fairy-types such as Mega Diancie, while Dazzling Gleam eliminates Mega Sableye's passivity in front of Hydreigon and Roaring Moon. Will-O-Wisp in conjunction with Prankster renders physical attackers like Mega Gallade, Dragonite, and Mamoswine less threatening. The given EV spread avoids a 2HKO from Life Orb Nidoking's Earth Power, assuming Mega Sableye uses Knock Off after the first Earth Power. Mimikyu threatens Dark-types such as Mandibuzz, Galarian Moltres, and opposing Mega Sableye. Spectrier breaks past walls like Toxapex, Gliscor, and Tapu Fini and appreciates Mega Sableye burning offensive threats to strengthen its setup potential. Gholdengo checks Fairy-types such as Tapu Lele, Mega Diancie, and Iron Valiant as well as preventing foes from removing entry hazards set by Froslass and Galarian Corsola. Blacephalon handles opposing Gholdengo and utilizes Choice Scarf to clean through Steel, Ghost, and Psychic teams once Heatran, Mega Sableye, and Galarian Slowking, respectively, are removed. Skeledirge has great synergy with Mega Sableye, appreciating the prevention of opposing Stealth Rock and in return walling Volcarona, Mega Lopunny, and Alolan Ninetales.

sets.name: Offensive Dragon Dance (Dragon)
sets.description: Mega Altaria's unique typing and offensive potential allow it to serve as a valuable setup sweeper that checks threats like Kommo-o, Roaring Moon, Iron Hands, and Keldeo. Pixilate-boosted Return checks the aforementioned Dragon-types as well as Fighting- and Dark-types such as Terrakion, Mega Sableye, and Mandibuzz. Earthquake is essential coverage, as it hits Steel- and Fire-types like Heatran and Magnezone and—in conjunction with Return—eases the Dark and Electric matchups. Roost increases Mega Altaria's longevity so it can continuously Dragon Dance throughout the match or use its bulk to switch into threats. The given EV spread allows Mega Altaria to survive Mega Lopunny's Triple Axel. Choice Specs Kyurem is a great teammate, as it breaks past the likes of Toxapex, Corviknight, and Dondozo for Mega Altaria. Garchomp sets up Stealth Rock and Spikes, wearing down Mega Altaria's switch-ins. Kommo-o breaks past Steel-types like Skarmory, Aegislash, and defensive Celesteela as well as other troublesome walls like Toxapex and Hippowdon for Mega Altaria. Roaring Moon threatens obstacles such as Mega Diancie, Choice Specs Greninja, and Skeledirge.

sets.name: Physically Defensive (Normal)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Physically Defensive (Ground)
sets.description: Gastrodon is a mainstay on Ground teams due to its vast utility options, great bulk along with reliable recovery, and a stellar ability in Storm Drain, checking a myriad of Water-types like Mega Swampert, Barraskewda, and Keldeo. Scald threatens physical attackers such as Dragonite, Mega Lopunny, and Mimikyu with a burn. Thanks to Gastrodon's bulk, it is able to stack multiple layers of Spikes to wear down opposing teams. Alternatively, Stealth Rock can be used, freeing a moveslot from a teammate such as Garchomp or Hippowdon. Toxic puts troublesome walls such as Mantine, Ting-Lu, and Araquanid on a timer. Earthquake may be used alongside a Relaxed nature to break Calm Mind Keldeo's Substitute. All of Gastrodon's teammates appreciate its ability to switch into Water-type attacks. Unaware Clodsire checks Grass-types such as Meowscarada and Tapu Bulu as well as setup sweepers Gastrodon can't beat like Volcarona and Galarian Moltres. Iron Treads removes entry hazards with Rapid Spin so Gastrodon can better perform its defensive duties. Wallbreakers like Landorus and Great Tusk appreciate Gastrodon's entry hazard support so that they can net more damage. Mamoswine acts as a secondary Ice-type switch-in that checks the likes of SubRoost Kyurem and Alolan Ninetales, relieving pressure off of Gastrodon.

sets.name: Specially Defensive (Steel)
sets.description: Heatran is a mainstay on Steel teams due to its ability, Flash Fire, letting it switch into threats like Blacephalon, Victini, and Iron Moth. Lava Plume makes Heatran annoying to switch into thanks to its burn chance, while Magma Storm softens walls like Toxapex and Rotom-W by trapping them. Earth Power threatens Poison- and Fire-types and makes Heatran an important asset against opposing Steel teams by hitting opposing Heatran. Roar lets Heatran phaze the likes of Nasty Plot Hydreigon and Z-Celebrate Victini and synergizes well with Stealth Rock to deal extra damage. Alternatively, Toxic cripples walls like Mantine and Rotom-W, as well as Pokemon that fancy switching into Heatran such as Volcarona and Mega Charizard Y. Substitute pairs well with Toxic (RC) and allows Heatran to be massively annoying against types like Steel, Electric, and Psychic by capitalizing on the many switches it forces in these matchups. Thanks to their typing and bulk, Corviknight and Celesteela are excellent teammates to check Ground- and Fighting-types like Mamoswine and Great Tusk for Heatran. Setup sweepers like Mega Scizor and Z-Happy Hour Jirachi appreciate Heatran wearing down teams with burn and Toxic. Iron Treads removes entry hazards with Rapid Spin and deals with Mega Charizard Y, Zeraora, and Cinderace with its Choice Scarf set. Ferrothorn checks Water-types like Mega Swampert and Urshifu-R and aids Heatran with Spikes and Leech Seed.

sets.name: Offensive Quiver Dance (Bug)
sets.description: Volcarona is one of Bug's strongest setup sweepers, with a respectable Speed stat, high Special Attack, and great coverage. In addition to being one of very few special attacking options on Bug, Volcarona helps apply pressure in a variety of matchups thanks to its strong STAB moves and coverage. Fire Blast can be used over Fiery Dance for more immediate damage output. Giga Drain deals with Water- and Ground-types, most notably Swampert, Gastrodon, and Rotom-Wash. Bug Buzz can be used instead for Volcarona to overwhelm types like Dragon, Dark, and Psychic with Quiver Dance-boosted STAB attacks. Hidden Power Ground hits Heatran, allowing Volcarona to break Steel's immunity-based defensive core that can otherwise give Bug teams problems. Alternatively, Psychic can be used to damage bulky Poison-types, like Toxapex and Mega Venusaur, that can wall physical attackers like Heracross and Buzzwole. These physical attackers, in addition to Lokix and Scizor, are able to break through specially defensive walls, like Chansey and Mantine, that Volcarona struggles against. Araquanid and Armaldo provide helpful entry hazards in Sticky Web and Stealth Rock, respectively, to make sweeping mid- or late-game much easier.

sets.name: Offensive Quiver Dance (Fire)
sets.description: Volcarona is one of the top setup sweepers that Fire has access to, with Quiver Dance allowing it to become a dangerous threat to teams unequipped to deal with it defensively. Psychic allows Volcarona to pressure Fighting and Poison teams, especially after one Quiver Dance, which lets Volcarona outspeed and beat Keldeo, Glimmora, and Crobat. Similarly, Giga Drain does the same to Water and Ground teams after one Quiver Dance, threatening Tapu Fini, Gastrodon, and Hippowdon. Bug Buzz covers the Psychic and Dark matchups very well and allows it to hit Roaring Moon, Ting-Lu, and Latias, which would otherwise be a challenge to deal with. Heavy-Duty Boots prevents Volcarona from being worn down by entry hazards, most notably Stealth Rock, which would otherwise stop Volcarona from being able to set up safely. Psychium Z lets Volcarona OHKO Toxapex with a +1 Shattered Psyche and beat otherwise troublesome threats like +1 Kommo-o, Iron Hands, and Clodsire. Cinderace and Mega Charizard X are especially good partners due to their ability to break through special walls such as Blissey, Clodsire, and Galarian Slowking with relative ease. Entry hazard removers such as Torkoal, Rotom-H, and Court Change Cinderace are near necessities if Volcarona is running Psychium Z. Torkoal and Rotom-H can also provide excellent utility in the form of Stealth Rock and dual screens, respectively, to help Volcarona sweep more easily. Volcanion is also an excellent partner for Volcarona that, thanks to its Water immunity, can act as a strong pivot into Pokemon like Azumarill and Mantine, which could revenge kill it or clear Quiver Dance boosts with Haze.

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Flying)
sets.description: Choice Scarf Landorus-T is one of the best revenge killers Flying teams have access to, outrunning threats like Tapu Koko, Mega Diancie, and Terrakion while boasting great firepower. It's also very desirable thanks to its defensive traits, which include an immunity to Electric-type attacks and Intimidate. U-turn takes advantage of the switches Landorus-T forces, allowing it to pivot out of walls that come in on it such as Corviknight and Mega Venusaur. Similarly, Knock Off cripples some of the bulky Pokemon it invites in, like Porygon2 and Ferrothorn, by removing their items. Stone Edge notably hits Kyurem the hardest and is Landorus-T's best move versus Flying-types like Zapdos and Pelipper. Alternatively, Explosion lets Landorus-T score a surprise KO against an offensive threat it normally cannot OHKO, such as Keldeo or Mega Lopunny. Special wallbreakers like Galarian Moltres, Tornadus-T, and Mega Charizard Y are great partners to deal with the aforementioned physical walls Landorus-T draws in. Thundurus-T relieves pressure from Landorus-T by acting as a secondary Electric immunity and is a great asset against the Water and Flying teams Landorus-T can't do much to. Mega Aerodactyl is able to form a powerful revenge killing core alongside Landorus-T while providing Stealth Rock support for it to clean teams more easily. Corviknight switches into most Ice-type attacks aimed at Landorus-T, removes Stealth Rock with Defog, and is able to bring Landorus-T safely onto the field via its slow U-turn.

sets.name: Bulk Up (Ground)
sets.description:
Ferrothorn's Power Whip does not break Substitute at +1 Def or -1 Atk from Intimidate.

This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Water)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Screen Setter (Fairy)
sets.description: Klefki is the ideal dual screens setter on Fairy due to its Steel typing, which negates Poison-type attacks from Nihilego and Alolan Muk and ability to fend off threats like Mega Scizor with Foul Play. Klefki is a better option than Grimmsnarl due to its typing and ability to set up Spikes, which, like its screens, go up quickly with Prankster. This support allows for Pokemon like Tapu Bulu and Azumarill from setting up and sweeping, teams. Foul Play prevents Pokemon like Mega Scizor and Mimikyu to set up and sweep while Thunder Wave cripples foes and allows Mega Diancie to outspeed threats such as +1 Mega Charizard X and Nihilego, which will normally beat Klefki one on one. Setting up Spikes creates solid chip damage on Alolan Muk and Gholdengo, allowing for late-game sweeping from its teammates Iron Valiant and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele. Mega Diancie punishes opponents trying to set up entry hazards against Klefki and beats Fire-types such as Heatran and Mega Charizard Y. Tapu Bulu helps Klefki with Grassy Terrain, which halves the damage it takes from Earthquake, making Pokemon such as Iron Treads and Mamoswine not hit as hard.

sets.name: Mixed Wallbreaker (Rock)
sets.description: Mega Diancie is the ideal Mega Evolution for Rock teams due to its ability to check Dragon-types like Kommo-o, punish passive Pokemon and entry hazard setters such as Toxapex and Klefki with Magic Bounce, and be a mixed wallbreaker that threatens Great Tusk and Galarian Slowking. Diamond Storm does considerable damage to special walls like Blissey and Alolan Muk and can also provide a Defense boost. Psychic heavily damages Mega Venusaur, Toxapex, and Nidoking, which eases the matchup against Poison teams. Earth Power deals heavy damage to Steel-type Pokemon like Heatran and Iron Treads and is paired nicely with Mystical Fire to damage Skarmory and Corviknight. On a hyper offensive team, Mega Diancie runs four attacks for coverage. With Shuckle's Sticky Web up, its good Speed tier becomes more devastating and outspeeds Pokemon like Mega Gallade and Zeraora. Mega Diancie also pairs well with Omastar and Terrakion, as Omastar takes care of the Ground matchup with a well-timed Shell Smash, while Terrakion's access to Earthquake and Close Combat takes care of most Steel-types. On bulky offense, Mega Diancie prefers to run Spikes, as the chip damage sets up a potential late-game cleanup from more offensive Pokemon on the team like Terrakion and Nihilego. Garganacl pairs well with Spikes, as Salt Cure forces a lot of Pokemon to switch out and take additional chip damage.

sets.name: Wallbreaker (Fairy)
sets.description: Mega Diancie is a valuable asset to Fairy teams, featuring Magic Bounce to deflect entry hazards and status, wide coverage, and strong offensive capabilities with its high Speed. Diamond Storm often increases Mega Diancie's bulk and threatens foes like Enamorus and Mega Charizard Y. Moonblast handles threats like Mega Sableye and Latias. Earth Power can be used to counter Steel teams, OHKOing Heatran, Excadrill, and Magnezone, while dealing heavy damage to the likes of Skeledirge and Garganacl. Mystical Fire targets Steel-types that don't mind Earth Power, such as Ferrothorn, Celesteela, and Mega Scizor under Psychic Terrain. Alternatively, Mega Diancie can run Nature Power and use the various terrains set by its teammates to expand its wallbreaking abilities. Stealth Rock can be used to allow Mega Diancie to set its own hazard, but four attacks are recommended given Mega Diancie's wide coverage. Klefki provides Spikes and dual screens support which allows Mega Diancie to OHKO threats like Gholdengo, and it can also carry Thunder Wave to let Mega Diancie outspeed and take out threats like Mega Gallade and Spectrier. Tapu Koko takes on Water-types and aids in the Steel matchup by forcing out Corviknight and Celesteela. Tapu Bulu counters Ground- and Water-types like Great Tusk and Urshifu-R, while Tapu Lele takes on Poison-types and prevents priority moves from Azumarill and Mega Scizor. Iron Valiant is a great partner for the Steel matchup, but it also benefits from Tapu Koko's Electric Terrain to outspeed and take out faster threats such as Zeraora and Greninja. All of these teammates appreciate Mega Diancie's ability to bounce hazards back to the opponent, as Fairy teams do not possess entry hazard removal.

sets.name: Physically Defensive (Water)
sets.description: Toxapex is an incredible asset to Water teams due to its great defensive profile and wide range of utility options. Scald burns physical attackers such as Dragonite and Mega Lopunny, as well as Garchomp and Mega Gallade attempting to switch in. Poison Jab threatens Fairy- and Grass-types like Tapu Bulu, Iron Valiant, and Rillaboom. Toxic Spikes enhances offensive teammates such as Barraskewda, Mega Swampert, and Greninja, while Toxic lessens Toxapex's passivity, putting Gastrodon, Tornadus-T, and Mega Altaria on a timer. Haze allows Toxapex to shut down setup sweepers like Mega Scizor, Mimikyu, and Mega Altaria. Knock Off bothers item-reliant walls such as Porygon2, Galarian Corsola, and Celesteela. Black Sludge allows Toxapex to outlast tankier foes with the help of chip damage from Toxic Spikes and Toxic, while Heavy-Duty Boots enables it as a pivot, letting it sponge attacks without worrying about entry hazards. Teammates appreciate Toxapex absorbing Toxic Spikes and fighting off Grass-types like Meowscarada and Breloom. Toxapex appreciates Slowking and Rotom-W taking Psychic- and Ground-type moves, respectively. Mega Swampert switches into Electric-types like Tapu Koko, Zapdos, and Magnezone and threatens Poison-types like opposing Toxapex, Clodsire, and Nidoking. Gastrodon forms a great defensive core with Toxapex, taking on the aforementioned Electric-types and providing entry hazards to further chip down pivots such as Meowscarada, Mega Lopunny, and Iron Moth. Greninja checks Ground-types like Clodsire, Garchomp, and Landorus and aids in the Flying matchup. Urshifu-R checks Pokemon like Kyurem and Hydreigon, which take advantage of Toxapex. Pelipper provides a Ground immunity against Landorus-T, Iron Treads, and Great Tusk and synergizes well with Toxapex against Grass teams.

sets.name: Physically Defensive (Poison)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Swords Dance (Ghost)
sets.description: Mimikyu is an outstanding asset to Ghost teams, boasting both a valuable part-Fairy typing and a unique ability that complements revenge killing and late-game cleaning. Play Rough hits threatening Dark- and Dragon-types like Galarian Moltres, Mandibuzz, and Kommo-o. Shadow Claw notably allows Mimikyu to threaten Psychic teams even under Psychic Terrain, while Drain Punch deals more damage to Steel-types such as Iron Treads, Magnezone, and Excadrill and can mitigate Life Orb recoil. Shadow Sneak enables Mimikyu to revenge kill weakened foes and pick off faster threats like Blacephalon, Gengar, and Victini. Disguise almost always allows Mimikyu to set up a Swords Dance or revenge kill faster foes that Shadow Sneak cannot deal enough damage to. Mega Sableye is heavily appreciated due to its ability Magic Bounce, which adds to Mimikyu's longevity by bouncing back entry hazards and status moves aimed at it. Wallbreakers like Spectrier and Gholdengo wear down bulkier teams by checking walls such as Corviknight, Mega Venusaur, and Toxapex, which lets Mimikyu have an easier time cleaning up late-game. Blacephalon and Skeledirge threaten the Steel-types Mimikyu struggles against, like Ferrothorn, Corviknight, and Mega Scizor. They can also cripple troublesome walls such as Toxapex and Gastrodon with Trick and Will-O-Wisp, respectively. Hisuian Zoroark is deeply valued for its Ghost-type immunity, as it can catch Spectrier, Gholdengo, and Gengar off guard.

sets.name: Z-Move Wallbreaker
sets.description: With a stellar ability in Grim Neigh, monstrous Special Attack and Speed stats, and good coverage, Spectrier has cemented itself as a premier threat residing in Ghost's shadows. Draining Kiss gives Spectrier a tool to threaten Dark-types such as Hydreigon and Weavile and excellent neutral coverage, as well as a method of recovery. When paired with Fairium Z, Draining Kiss also lets Spectrier be an amazing asset against Normal teams; the move allows it to beat Porygon2 and Blissey, while a Nasty Plot-boosted Twinkle Tackle dispatches the likes of Diggersby and Hisuian Zoroark. Substitute takes advantage of the switches Spectrier forces so it can boost more easily and protects Spectrier from being easily revenge killed or statused. Mimikyu and Spectrier make for a fearsome duo; Spectrier pressures many of Mimikyu's checks such as Toxapex and Corviknight, and Mimikyu threatens the likes of Tyranitar and Ting-Lu. Choice Scarf Blacephalon takes advantage of Spectrier's wallbreaking to more easily clean late game. It also picks off faster Pokemon like Mega Lopunny and Deoxys-S for Spectrier. Mega Sableye is an excellent switch-in to most Ghost-type attacks aimed at Spectrier thanks to its typing and bulk and serves as an entry hazard deterrent thanks to Magic Bounce. Entry hazard setters like Galarian Corsola and Froslass are great partners to help Spectrier net more KOs. Skeledirge disrupts physical attackers like Mega Scizor and Rillaboom with Will-O-Wisp and wears down defensive switch-ins to Spectrier with Torch Song and Hex.

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Dark)
sets.description: Thanks to its fantastic movepool and Protean, Choice Scarf Meowscarada is the best revenge killer available for Dark teams, outrunning the likes of Regieleki, Speed-boosted Kommo-o, and Mega Swampert under rain. Flower Trick is Meowscarada's most powerful move, picking off weakened foes such as Tapu Lele and Terrakion. Play Rough is essential, as it deals with many threats to Dark teams like Galarian Zapdos, Mega Gallade, and Iron Valiant. U-turn allows Meowscarada to switch out of unfavorable situations, pivoting into powerful teammates such as Galarian Moltres and Mega Tyranitar while keeping momentum for the team. Knock Off cripples defensive switch-ins—such as Toxapex, Ferrothorn, and Clefable—as well as offensive Pokemon like Zeraora and Iron Treads. Toxic Spikes can be run instead to better pressure Normal, Fairy, and Fighting teams. Meowscarada's teammates appreciate its ability to check a myriad of threats as well as its revenge killing capabilities. Wallbreakers like Galarian Moltres and Hydreigon are great partners to deal with physical walls like Celesteela and Mega Venusaur. Ting-Lu and Tyranitar provide entry hazard support for Meowscarada—ensuring it is able to net more KO's—and are great defensive pivots for it to fall back upon. Similarly, Mega Sableye provides a Fighting immunity, bounces back status moves, and prevents entry hazards from going up, letting Meowscarada switch in unscathed.

sets.name: Swords Dance (Fairy)
sets.description: Iron Valiant's combination of stats, typing, and coverage makes it an excellent wallbreaker for Fairy teams, capable of outrunning Mega Diancie, Nihilego, and Iron Treads. At +2 Attack, All-Out Pummeling OHKOes troublesome walls such as physically defensive Celesteela and Corviknight. Spirit Break notably breaks Mega Sableye, enabling Iron Valiant to greatly pressure Dark and Ghost teams. Knock Off deals with Ghost-types like Gholdengo and Aegislash, allowing Iron Valiant to heavily dent Steel. It also removes important items from Clodsire, Klefki, and Toxapex. Shadow Sneak can be used over Knock Off to pick off weakened foes like Spectrier and Blacephalon. Iron Valiant loves Klefki's ability to set dual screens and Spikes, as this allows Iron Valiant to set up more easily and deal with bulkier cores better. Tapu Lele sets Psychic Terrain, neutralizing Mega Scizor's Bullet Punch, and it also deals with Poison-types Iron Valiant has a hard time with, such as Mega Venusaur and Toxapex. Tapu Koko's Electric Terrain activates Iron Valiant's Quark Drive, letting it outspeed the likes of Mega Lopunny and Mega Swampert under rain. Tapu Bulu improves the Water and Ground matchups and removes bulky Water-types like Toxapex and Dondozo. Mega Diancie and Azumarill love Iron Valiant's ability to soften walls, as it allows them to clean up late-game.

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Fighting)
sets.description: Iron Valiant is one of Fighting teams' best assets with amazing qualities between its typing, Speed, and offenses. Choice Scarf accentuates its Speed further and lets it outspeed many threats to Fighting teams such as Tornadus-T, Spectrier, Tapu Koko, and Choice Scarf users such as Tapu Lele and Galarian Zapdos. Its STAB Moonblast is one of its best qualities, being able to easily beat Mega Sableye and OHKO most opposing Fighting- and Dragon-types such as Buzzwole and Mega Altaria. Thunderbolt is great coverage to hit Flying- and Water-types like Tornadus-T and Toxapex that otherwise wall Iron Valiant, while Energy Ball lets it deal with Mega Swampert, which it can outspeed even under rain, Rotom-W, and Gastrodon more easily. Shadow Ball prevents Iron Valiant from being walled by Gholdengo, Skeledirge, and Aegislash while also improving the Psychic matchup. Knock Off and Trick cripple defensive switch-ins such as Toxapex, Celesteela, and Clodsire by removing or replacing important items and forcing them to go without passive recovery or be Choice locked. Iron Valiant is also a great asset in the Fairy and Electric matchups, as it uses opposing Tapu Koko's Electric Surge to activate its own Quark Drive and outspeed even Regieleki and Alolan Raichu under Electric Terrain. Iron Valiant appreciates support from Mega Gallade, as it easily takes care of Poison-types like Clodsire, Mega Venusaur, and Alolan Muk. Iron Hands and Great Tusk are great teammates for the Electric matchup while also beating the likes of Toxapex, Galarian Moltres, and Gholdengo. Cobalion and Great Tusk can set up Stealth Rock and even clear entry hazards in the case of the latter. Cobalion also helps against Fairy-types such as Tapu Bulu and Tapu Lele, while Great Tusk helps deal with Tapu Koko and Assault Vest Iron Hands. Choice Band Urshifu-R is a great ally to beat Fire-types such as Volcarona and Skeledirge and Ground-types such as Landorus-T and Excadrill. Kommo-o deals with bulky Water-, Fire-, and Grass-types like Toxapex, Skeledirge, and Mega Venusaur with its massive Clangorus Soulblaze in conjunction with Taunt. Breloom is also a natural counter to Water-types, being able to deal with Swampert, and hindering defensive walls such as Toxapex with Spore. Galarian Zapdos is another great teammate that can weaken foes and safely get in Iron Valiant with U-turn.
